﻿1. Overview
Pokémon TCG Pocket is a streamlined mobile adaptation of the physical Pokémon Trading Card Game. Battles use compact 20‑card decks, automatic Energy generation, and a point‑based win condition, keeping games under five minutes.
2. Components
* Deck – Exactly 20 cards (no basic Energy). Maximum two copies of the same card name.

* Energy Zone – A shared pool that produces one Energy automatically each turn.

* Play Area – One Active Pokémon and up to three Benched Pokémon.

* Points Tracker – First player to reach 3 points wins.

3. Deck Construction
   1. Build a 20‑card list containing only Pokémon and Trainer cards.



   2. You may include at most two copies of any card sharing the same English name.

   3. Every deck must contain exactly two copies of Professor’s Research.


      4. Effects that draw cards (Pokeball, Professors Research, Sylveon EX) are to be considered very positively



      5. During deck creation you select one or more basic Energy types; the Energy Zone will only ever generate those types.Energy cards do not exist.










4. Game Setup
         1. Each player shuffles and draws 5 cards. The app guarantees at least one Basic Pokémon (no mulligans).
         2. Because the hands are randomly drawn, there is no guarantee of opening with the pokemon you want. Being able to adapt and having more than one win condition is crucial.

         3. Both players place a Basic Pokémon Active and up to three on the Bench.





5. Turn Structure
Phase
	Actions
	Start
	Resolve start‑of‑turn effects. (On the very first turn, the starting player skips their Draw phase.)
	Draw
	Draw one card.
	Energy Zone Refresh
	If your Zone was empty at the end of last turn, it produces one Energy that remains until used. If any Energy is left unused, no new Energy is generated.
	Manual Attachment
	Once per turn, move one Energy from your Zone onto a Pokémon (the starting player cannot do this on turn 1).
	Main Actions
	Play Basic Pokémon; evolve ; play any number of Item and Pokémon Tool cards; play one Supporter card (total) per turn; retreat your Active Pokémon once per turn; etc.
	Attack
	Attack with your Active Pokémon if it meets the Energy cost (some attacks cost 0).
	Pokémon Checkup
	Resolve Special Conditions and end‑of‑turn effects, then check for Knock Outs.
	End
	Pass to the opponent. Unused Energy still in the Zone prevents next turn’s refresh.
	6. Victory Conditions
            * Point System – KO a regular Pokémon: 1 point; KO a Pokémon ex: 2 points. The first player to reach 3 points wins immediately.

            * Turn Limit – Versus battles end after 50 turns, Solo battles after 30 turns; the player with more points wins.

            * Running out of cards does not cause a loss.











7. Other key rules


               * Weakness adds a flat +20 damage;

               * Maximum hand size is 10; if you would exceed it, choose and discard until you have 10.

               * Confused Pokémon that flip tails no longer damage themselves (the attack simply fails).
               * Tool cards are played by attaching them to a Benched or Active Pokémon. Once a player attaches a Pokémon Tool to a Pokémon, the Pokémon Tool may only be removed by the effect of a card; removed Pokémon Tools are typically discarded, as are those attached to a Knocked Out Pokémon.

               * Effects that target a random Pokémon are decided by the app.

               * Attack locks (e.g., Buzzwole ex – Big Beat Loop) end as soon as the Pokémon leaves the Active spot.

               * You may play any number of Item and Pokémon Tool cards during your turn, but only one Supporter.

               * Pokémon cannot evolve the same turn they are played. Stage 1 Pokémon evolve from Basic Pokémon, Stage 2 from Stage 1, or directly from Basic when you use a Rare Candy.

               * You may retreat your Active Pokémon only once per turn.

8. Frequently Asked Rulings
                  * Zero‑Cost Attacks – An attack with no Energy symbols may be used at any time, including the opening turn.

                  * Buzzwole ex – Big Beat Loop – Switching Buzzwole ex to the Bench removes its self‑lock, allowing it to use Big Beat again next turn.

                  * Scizor – Gale Thrust – The +50 bonus applies only if Scizor became Active during your turn before attacking.











10. Status Effects (Special Conditions)
Special Conditions represent persistent afflictions that hinder a Pokémon. They are checked during Pokémon Checkup at the end of every player’s turn, always in this order:
Poison → Burn → Sleep → Paralysis
A Pokémon can be affected by multiple conditions simultaneously; resolve each separately in the sequence above.
10.1 Individual Effects
Status
	In‑Game Effect
	How to Cure
	Poisoned
	Put 1 damage counter (10) on the Pokémon at the end of each player’s turn.
	Evolve, move to Bench, or attach Lum Berry.
	Burned
	Put 2 damage counters (20) at the end of each player’s turn, then flip a coin; on Heads, Burn is removed.
	Same cures as Poison, plus the coin flip.
	Sleep
	The Pokémon cannot attack or retreat. At Checkup, flip a coin; on Heads, Sleep is removed.
	Wake via coin flip, evolve, Bench, or Lum Berry.
	Paralyzed
	The Pokémon cannot attack or retreat until the end of its controller’s next turn (guaranteed to wear off after one full turn).
	Wait one turn, evolve, or Lum Berry.
	Confused
	When the Pokémon declares an attack, flip a coin; on Tails, the attack fails (it does not self‑damage in Pocket).
	Bench, evolve, or Lum Berry.
	10.2 Timing & Damage Math
                     * Because Checkup occurs on both turns, Poison effectively deals 20 damage per round (10 on your turn, 10 on the opponent’s), and Burn deals 40 if not cured by Heads.

                     * Status damage is resolved before the next turn’s Start phase, so it can KO a Pokémon before you regain Energy.

                     * Paralysis has the shortest duration: exactly one full turn cycle.

                     * Sleep can potentially last indefinitely if you keep flipping Tails.

10.3 Universal Cures & Tech Cards
                        1. Evolve the affected Pokémon (removes all current Special Conditions).

                        2. Switch / Retreat to move it to the Bench. Note: Sleep or Paralysis normally prevent Retreat; use cards like Koga or Switch effects to force a change.

                        3. Lum Berry Pokémon Tool – Instantly removes one Special Condition upon attachment.

                        4. Wait out Paralysis or flip Heads for Sleep/Burn.

10.4 Interaction Notes
                           * Multiple copies of the same condition do not stack; only one instance is tracked.

                           * A knocked‑out Pokémon still awards points after all status damage is applied.

﻿Building a Competitive Pokémon TCG Pocket Deck
Pokémon TCG Pocket is a fast‑paced mobile card battler with a streamlined 20‑card deck format. Because every card slot is precious and battles end after 3 Prize Points, effective deck construction requires sharp focus and synergy. This guide covers the fundamentals of competitive deck building in Pocket—plus advanced tactics—without excluding any Pokémon type or play style.
________________


1. Core Rules & Format Essentials
* 20‑Card Decks – Every deck contains exactly 20 cards, comprising only Pokémon and Trainer cards. Trainers are divided into Supporters, Items and Tools. There are no basic Energy cards in Pocket 🗒️.

* Copy Limit 2 – A maximum of two copies of any card with the same name can be included.

* Prize Points – Players win by earning 3 Prize Points (1 point for knocking out a regular Pokémon, 2 points for a Pokémon ex).

* Bench Size 3 – You may keep up to three Pokémon on the Bench. If all your Pokémon are Knocked Out, you lose immediately.

* Energy Zone – Each turn you gain one free Energy attachment from a shared Energy Zone. Energy does not accumulate if unused.

* Up to 3 Energy Types – A deck may contain Pokémon whose attacks require no more than three different Energy types. Most competitive lists stick to one or two types for consistency.

________________


2. Pokémon–Trainer Ratios
A popular starting ratio is ≈ 8 Pokémon + 12  Trainers. Adjust to suit your strategy:
   * 5 ≥  Basic Pokémon for stable openings.

   * Focus on 1–2 evolution lines for consistency; avoid cramming several Stage 2 lines into 20 cards.


      * A maximum of 8-9 Pokemon per deck is preferred, but the best decks have even less than that. Less Pokémon mean more consistency and a better deck

      * Trainer slots should prioritize draw/search, type‑specific Supporters, and utility Items/Tools.

________________


3. Choosing a Main Attacker & Deck Theme
Pick one primary Pokémon (often a Pokémon ex) as your win condition, then build every other card to support that goal. Examples:
Attack Style
	Sample Main Pokémon ex
	Key Support
	Aggro (low‑cost, fast KO)
	Pikachu ex, Buzzwole ex
	Bench fillers of same type, damage buffs
	Powerhouse (build‑up, sweep)
	Charizard ex, Gyarados ex
	Walls to stall, energy acceleration
	Combo/Control
	Mewtwo ex, Venusaur ex
	Energy engines (e.g., Gardevoir), healing or gust effects
	Tip: Every supporting Pokémon should serve a clear role—backup attacker, energy accelerator, wall, bench booster, or tech counter. Aim for Pokémon that fulfill multiple roles to maximize each deck slot.
________________


4. Mastering the Energy Zone
         * Attach every turn—unused Energy is wasted.

         * Streamline types—fewer Energy types mean a higher chance of seeing the one you need.

         * Energy Acceleration—Abilities like Gardevoir’s Psy Shadow or Supporters like Misty provide extra attachments and are crucial for energy‑hungry Pokémon.

         * Plan for Discards/Retreats—discarded Energy leaves the pool for good; use free‑retreat options or Trainer cards that lower retreat cost.

________________


5. Staple Trainer Cards
Trainer Role
	Examples
	Why It’s Essential
	Draw/Search
	Professor’s Research, Poké Ball, Pokémon Communication
	Keeps your hand flowing in a 20‑card deck
	Type Supporter
	Misty (Water), Erika (Grass), Blaine (Fire), etc.
	Extra Energy, healing, or damage buffs for one type
	Damage Buff / Gust
	Giovanni, Sabrina, Cyrus
	Push attacks over KO threshold or target weak Bench Pokémon
	Retreat/Healing
	X Speed, Giant Cape, Potion
	Mitigate retreat costs and prolong survivability
	Tools
	Rocky Helmet, Giant Cape
	Punish attackers or raise HP on a tank
	Adapt quantities: fast aggro decks favor more draw; evolution decks want extra Pokémon search; bulky strategies may include multiple healing Items.
________________


6. Meta‑Ready Archetype Examples
            1. Lightning Aggro – Pikachu ex + Zapdos ex, aiming for Turn‑2 KOs. Includes Lt. Surge‑style Supporter for damage boost and maxes out draw/search.

            2. Fire Mid‑Range – Charizard ex backed by Moltres ex and Kangaskhan wall. Uses Blaine for damage and Inferno Dance for energy acceleration.

            3. Psychic Combo – Mewtwo ex + Gardevoir evolution line. Gardevoir fuels extra Psychic Energy each turn; deck packs draw and switch cards.

            4. Grass Stall/Heal – Venusaur ex with Erika, Potions, and Giant Cape. Focuses on longevity, slowly taking prizes while denying KOs.

            5. Fire/Fairy Dual‑Type – Charizard ex + Sylveon ex for matchup flexibility. Requires careful Energy Zone management but covers more threats.

________________


7. Testing & Refinement Checklist
               1. Track Consistency: Do you miss key evolutions or Supporters? Increase draw/search.

               2. Identify Dead Cards: Cut cards that rarely matter in real games.

               3. Cover Weak Matchups: Add tech Pokémon or Trainers that answer decks you lose to.

               4. Follow Expansion Updates: New sets (e.g., Wisdom of Sea & Sky, July 2025) can shift the meta—adapt accordingly.

               5. Iterate Constantly: Even a top‑tier deck list improves with tweaks after each match.

________________


8. Common Pitfalls to Avoid
                  * Over‑stuffing Types: Two Energy decks sounds tempting but usually hurts consistency.

                  * Too Many One‑Off Pokémon: Stick to a compact roster you can reliably draw.

                  * Ignoring Retreat Costs: High‑HP attackers often need help switching—plan for it.

                  * Under‑valuing Trainers: Skimping on Trainers cripples draw power and flexibility.
